intro: Mariscus boninsimae, commonly known as the Bonin mallow, is a flowering plant native to the Bonin Islands in Japan. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy, oval-shaped leaves and showy, pinkish-white flowers that bloom in summer. It thrives in coastal areas and is adapted to sandy, well-drained soils. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
